G.L. c. 218, \u00a7 19.proposition: Jurisdiction is proper in this Court pursuant to G.L. c. 218, § 19, as the property that is the subject of this action is situated in Springfield, Massachusetts, and the amount in controversy does not exceed the jurisdictional limit of the District Court.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 1.proposition: Venue is proper in the Springfield Division of the District Court Department pursuant to G.L. c. 223, § 1, because the property and parties are located in this district.

Massachusetts General Laws c. 186, \u00a.proposition: Defendant’s failure constitutes a breach of the statutory and common-law covenant of quiet enjoyment, as codified in Massachusetts General Laws c. 186, § 14.

G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 14.proposition: Under G.L. c. 186, § 14, a landlord may not “directly or indirectly interfere with the quiet enjoyment” of a tenant’s leased premises, whether by act or omission.

G.L. c. 239, \u00a7 8A.proposition: The duty to ensure essential services, including electricity, falls within the landlord’s obligations of maintenance under G.L. c. 186, § 14 and G.L. c. 239, § 8A; see also Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Mass. 196 (1979).

G.L. c. 186, \u00a714.proposition: Plaintiff is entitled to actual and consequential damages, and by statute, at least three months’ rent or actual damages, whichever is greater, under G.L. c. 186, §14, see also Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. at 102–103.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6C.proposition: D. For interest pursuant to G.L. c. 231, § 6C; and E. For such other and further relief as this Court deems just and proper.

Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).proposition: Massachusetts courts have consistently held that a landlord’s failure to timely repair serious defects affecting habitability or utility constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).support_reasoning: The opinion squarely treats repeated flooding and unsanitary conditions as both a breach of the implied warranty of habitability and an interference with the covenant/statutory right of quiet enjoyment. The court explains that “quiet enjoyment” covers serious interferences with the tenancy and holds Gem liable under G.L. c. 186, § 14 because its failure to maintain sanitary, watertight conditions and prevent repeated flooding interfered with the tenant’s quiet enjoyment. That directly supports the proposition that a landlord’s failure to timely repair serious habitability defects can constitute a breach of quiet enjoyment under Massachusetts law.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).relevant_excerpt: “The phrase ‘quiet enjoyment’ is a familiar term in landlord-tenant law, signifying the tenant’s right to freedom from serious interferences with his tenancy — acts or omissions that ‘impair the character and value of the leased premises.’… The water in Solomon’s apartment was a preventable situation, and one that Gem had a duty to prevent… The jury found… that the water interfered with Solomon’s quiet enjoyment of her apartment. Therefore, Gem is liable under G. L. c. 186, § 14.”

Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.proposition: Massachusetts courts have consistently held that a landlord’s failure to timely repair serious defects affecting habitability or utility constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.support_reasoning: The case does involve breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment and habitability, but the breach arises from excessive noise from a lounge the landlord allowed and could control, not from a failure to timely repair physical defects. The opinion discusses landlord conduct that creates or permits intolerable conditions (noise) as a constructive eviction, rather than delayed repairs of serious defects. Thus, it supports a broader rule about landlord-created or controllable conditions interfering with habitability, but not specifically the proposition about failure to timely repair serious defects.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.relevant_excerpt: “There are occasions, however, where a landlord has not intended to violate a tenant’s rights, but there was nevertheless a breach of the landlord’s covenant of quiet enjoyment which flowed as the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done… Because the disturbing condition was the natural and probable consequence of the landlords’ permitting the lounge to operate where it did and because the landlords could control the actions at the lounge, they should not be entitled to collect rent for residential premises which were not reasonably habitable.”

Manzaro v. McCann, 401 Mass. 880 (1988).proposition: Massachusetts courts have consistently held that a landlord’s failure to timely repair serious defects affecting habitability or utility constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
Manzaro v. McCann, 401 Mass. 880 (1988).support_reasoning: The opinion does address the covenant of quiet enjoyment, but it does so in the context of landlord-caused noise from a continuously ringing smoke alarm, not in the context of a failure to repair serious defects affecting habitability or utility. The holding is that substantial noise over a day from an alarm can constitute interference with quiet enjoyment; it does not discuss or establish any rule about untimely repairs or serious habitability defects. Thus, it does not support the specific proposition claimed.
Manzaro v. McCann, 401 Mass. 880 (1988).relevant_excerpt: “A landlord will be liable for interference with quiet enjoyment if he causes or authorizes acts which result in ‘substantial injury to the tenant in the peaceful enjoyment of the demised premises.’ … The covenant of quiet enjoyment protects the ‘tenant’s right to freedom from serious interferences with his tenancy.’ … Landlord-caused noise may be sufficient to support a claim for interference with a tenant’s right to quiet enjoyment.”

Dolloff v. School Comm. of Boston, 27 Ma.raw_text: Dolloff v. School Comm. of Boston, 27 Mass. App. Ct. 932 (1989)
Dolloff v. School Comm. of Boston, 27 Ma.proposition: Massachusetts courts have consistently held that a landlord’s failure to timely repair serious defects affecting habitability or utility constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.

Hemmingway v. Maurer, 9 Mass. App. Ct. 8.raw_text: Hemmingway v. Maurer, 9 Mass. App. Ct. 843 (1980)
Hemmingway v. Maurer, 9 Mass. App. Ct. 8.proposition: Massachusetts courts have consistently held that a landlord’s failure to timely repair serious defects affecting habitability or utility constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
Hemmingway v. Maurer, 9 Mass. App. Ct. 8.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns public employees’ ability to compel arbitration under a collective bargaining agreement and the duty of fair representation by a union. It does not address landlord‑tenant law, habitability, utility defects, or the covenant of quiet enjoyment. Therefore, it provides no support for the claimed proposition about Massachusetts landlords’ repair obligations and quiet enjoyment.
Hemmingway v. Maurer, 9 Mass. App. Ct. 8.relevant_excerpt: An employee, unsupported by his union, may not compel arbitration. An exception to this general rule is made if bad faith or arbitrary or discriminatory conduct by his union has prevented an employee from obtaining arbitration. The plaintiffs have not claimed any breach of the Association’s duty of representation.

Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.raw_text: Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Mass. 196 (1979)
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.proposition: The duty to ensure essential services, including electricity, falls within the landlord’s obligations of maintenance under G.L. c. 186, § 14 and G.L. c. 239, § 8A; see also Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Mass. 196 (1979).
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely concerns heat and hot water failures as breaches of the implied warranty of habitability and the effect on rent abatement. It discusses G.L. c. 239, § 8A and the sanitary code obligations to provide heat and hot water, but it does not address electricity or frame a general rule that all ‘essential services, including electricity’ fall within the landlord’s obligations of maintenance under G.L. c. 186, § 14 and c. 239, § 8A. Using this case as authority specifically for a duty to ensure electricity overstates what the decision holds.
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “The Code puts the landlord on notice that it must supply adequate heat and hot water. State Sanitary Code, Art. II, Regulations 5, 6 (1969) (current version at 105 Code Mass. Regs. 410.190, 410.200, 410.201). The landlord can have no reasonable grounds to believe that noncompliance will be acceptable.”

Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.raw_text: Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. 273 (1994)
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.proposition: Defendant’s ongoing omission constitutes an interference “by act or omission” as described in G.L. c. 186, § 14 and elaborated in Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. 273 (1994) (“landlord liable under §14 when conduct foreseeably and substantially interferes with tenant’s use”).
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.support_reasoning: The court squarely interprets G.L. c. 186, § 14’s “directly or indirectly interferes” language to include landlord liability based on omissions, not just affirmative acts, and explains that a breach occurs when serious interference is the “natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done.” It further holds that if the landlord has failed to take measures to remove disruptive nontenants and that failure foreseeably and seriously interferes with tenants’ use, the landlord may be liable under § 14. That reasoning directly supports characterizing an ongoing omission as an “interference by act or omission” when it foreseeably and substantially impairs the tenancy.
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “The covenant of quiet enjoyment protects a tenant’s right to freedom from serious interference with his tenancy — acts or omissions that impair the character and value of the leasehold. … In analyzing whether there is a breach of the covenant, we examine the landlord’s conduct and not his intentions. Thus, a landlord may not intend to violate a tenant’s right to quiet enjoyment, but may do so nevertheless when the breach is a ‘natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done.’ … If the defendant failed to take any action to remove from the area of its control persons engaged in unlawful activity, then the defendant permitted a condition to exist that substantially interfered with the tenancies of the plaintiffs and thus breached the covenant of quiet enjoyment.”

Lipsitt v. Plaud, 466 Mass. 240 (2013).proposition: The interruption of adequate utility service has repeatedly been held to amount to a substantial interference with tenants’ quiet enjoyment.
Lipsitt v. Plaud, 466 Mass. 240 (2013).support_reasoning: The opinion in Lipsitt v. Plaud concerns whether the Massachusetts Wage Act preempts common-law contract and quasi-contract claims for unpaid wages and whether the plaintiff sufficiently pleaded veil‑piercing. It does not address landlord‑tenant law, quiet enjoyment, or the effect of interrupted utility services on tenants’ rights. Therefore, it cannot be cited as authority for the proposition regarding substantial interference with tenants’ quiet enjoyment due to interruption of utility service.

Melendez v. Autogermana, Inc., 622 F.3d.raw_text: Melendez v. Autogermana, Inc., 622 F.3d 46 (1st Cir. 2010)
Melendez v. Autogermana, Inc., 622 F.3d.proposition: The interruption of adequate utility service has repeatedly been held to amount to a substantial interference with tenants’ quiet enjoyment.
Melendez v. Autogermana, Inc., 622 F.3d.support_reasoning: The case is an ADEA employment discrimination decision about an allegedly discriminatory discharge of a car salesman. It does not concern landlord-tenant law, quiet enjoyment, or interruptions of utility service, nor does it discuss what constitutes substantial interference with tenants’ quiet enjoyment. Therefore, it cannot be authority for the proposition that interruption of adequate utility service is a substantial interference with quiet enjoyment.

Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. at 102\u2013.proposition: Plaintiff is entitled to actual and consequential damages, and by statute, at least three months’ rent or actual damages, whichever is greater, under G.L. c. 186, §14, see also Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. at 102–103.
